xxl.core.binarySearchTrees
Class BinarySearchTree.Node

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.binarySearchTrees.BinarySearchTree.Node
Direct Known Subclasses:
AVLTree.Node, BBTree.Node, RedBlackTree.Node
Enclosing class:
BinarySearchTree
public class BinarySearchTree.Node
extends java.lang.Object

Nodes in a BinarySearchTree are of the type Node.

public BinarySearchTree.Node child(boolean right)
Returns the left or right child.

Parameters:

Node - returns the right(left) child if true(false)

isLeaf

public boolean isLeaf()
Tests if the node is a leaf.

Returns:
boolean - true if the current node is a leaf

index

public int index()
Returns 0(1) if this node is the left(right) son of its parent. If the node is the root-node -1 is returned.

Returns:
int - returns the index of the current node from the parent point of view.

index

public int index(BinarySearchTree.Node child)
Returns the index of 'child'. If 'child' is not a child of this node -1 is returned.

Parameters:
child - the child whose index is searched
Returns:
int - index of a child.

next

public BinarySearchTree.Node next(int index)
Returns the symmetric predecessor (index=0) or or successor (index=1) for this node.

Parameters:
index - 0 for symmetric predecessor or 1 for symmetric successor
Returns:
Node - returns the symmetric predecessor or successor.

fix

protected void fix(int index)
This method is called when a structural change occures (e.g. during an insert()- or remove()-operation) in one of the subtrees. In a BinarySearchTree-Object this method has nothing to do. It is usually overwritten in subclasses.

Parameters:
index -
See Also:
AVLTree, RedBlackTree, BBTree

designate

protected void designate(BinarySearchTree.Node next)
This method has to be implemented in case that a rotation invalidates information of the node. This method should copy the information from this node to the node next. In a BinarySearchTree-Object this method has nothing to do. It is usually overwritten in subclasses.

Parameters:
next - destination for the rotation information.
See Also:
AVLTree, RedBlackTree

rotate

protected BinarySearchTree.Node rotate()
This method is called for the son of the rotation, i.e. after the rotation the son is the new father-node. This method calls fixRotation() (for the new son) and fixAggregate() (for father and son). It is assumed, that the aggregates of the parents of the new root of the subtree are not affected.

Returns:
Node - this

get

public BinarySearchTree.Node get(java.util.Comparator chooseSubtree,
                                 java.lang.Object[] object,
                                 int[] result)
Exactmatch query. Locates an object in the tree in the current node or below.

Parameters:
chooseSubtree - Comparator that is used to find the requested object.
object - Object[] that contains the object.
result - int[] that contains a return value (see "Returns").
Returns:
Node that contains the object or the node where the search had to be terminated (result[0] is set to 0 if the object was found, <0 if object is left of that node, >0 if greater than the node)

insert

public BinarySearchTree.Node insert(java.util.Comparator chooseSubtree,
                                    java.lang.Object[] object)
Inserts an object into the tree. This method locates the correct position for the object in the tree and inserts the given object.

Parameters:
chooseSubtree - Comparator that is used to locate the place where the object becomes inserted.
object - Object[] that contains the object.
Returns:
null if the tree did not contain the object. Otherwise the node that already contains the object (if it is already in the tree) is returned. In the latter case there are no changes in the tree.

insert

public void insert(int index,
                   java.lang.Object object)
Appends an object to one of the children-nodes.

Parameters:
index - Position where to insert the new node into the children array.
object - contains the object.

remove

public BinarySearchTree.Node remove(java.util.Comparator chooseSubtree,
                                    java.lang.Object[] object,
                                    int nextIndex)
Locates the object and removes it from the tree.

Parameters:
chooseSubtree - Comparator that is used to locate the place where the object is located.
object - Object[] that contains the object.
nextIndex - index of the object to be removed
Returns:
null if the tree did not contain the object. Otherwise the node that has contained the object before the remove-operation is returned.

remove

public void remove(int nextIndex)
Removes the child node with number nextIndex from the current node. This operation is implemented a little bit different compared to the remove algorithm that is proposed in many books. It looks for the successor-node and rotates him below the node ... This method is more generic, because it works with every type of tree that is subclassed from BinarySearchTree.

Parameters:
nextIndex -
